Is a reductionist view tautological? Or lead to tautological reasoning? I.e., The method of reductionism proves only that the method can reduce systems down to individual components; and, the evidence that it understands the whole system is just the fact that it can reduce it down to its constituent parts? So the reasoning becomes tautological in the same way that in social sciences 'structural functionalism' is tautological in saying that everything that exists serves a function, and the evidence that it serves a function is that it exists.

@1:12:28 i'm going to say that robert sapolsky has become my favourite person this year and i've watched all his lectures up until now, but i have to step up here because he's not explaining something right and i thing it might clear things a bit. I can feel he's not an expert on mathematics: The thing is coordinates do actually repeat, as this is a direct implication from any given lines crossing eachother (two lines that cross, by definition, is that they share at least one point in common). In the graph he draw (aswell as the one he's reffering to, which i know because i did maths and i also read the book Chaos), there's an infinite number of lines crossing at eachtoher all the times, thus, there's infinite lines which share infite points with other lines. So YES, you do get point coordinates from different patches of curve that are exactly the same, and that is at the crossings, which DO exist. Where these minor variations he's giving so much importance occur (this is what i thing he's not understanding well), is not at the coordinates each curve seems to cross another one, but at the inclination each curve has on any given crossing. The inclination shows where each curve is going to, so if the inclination at a point where 2 curves cross doesnt correlate, you know those 2 curves are not the same, and thus they will follow different paths afterwards.  Summing up: curves DO cross eachother, and where the minor variations occur, is at the angle each curve has on any given crossing. If you found a crossing where 2 curves had the same inclination, then those curves would be the same, and you'd had found a periodic system.  Hope i clarified it for someone.

18:14 It is nice to have a broad view of what is going on, such as the Philosophy of Broader Survival or such as noting that 'variability' is occurring, but you can lose yourself in an erroneous rabbit hole by trying to apply the reduction of variability blindly. A case in point are perspectives. Everything has many valid partial perspectives (from different angles or from different levels) which you would want to combine into a whole. Trying to reduce a variety of perspective (the variability) to one perspective would be counterproductive, since you would be discarding all of the other equally valid perspectives from different vantage points, each a useful tool for various problems. A specific case is trying to define 'life'. If you try to deduce it down to one sentence, then you are being foolish, since 'life' can be correctly described from many vantage points (physics: atoms; chemistry: molecules; biology: cells; taxonomy: body plans; mechanics: machines; systems theory: self-regulation; consciousness: self-preservation; philosophy: proaction vs. reaction), just as it can be classified in many useful (but non-universal) ways. So you have to be careful when deconstructing something, or you may be throwing out all but one of your tools in your toolbox when there is more than one problem still to solve out there and which require different tools.   As for human behavior, the Philosophy of Broader Survival sums it up at the broadest level: i.e. that so far, humans have been Universally Clueless (as defined by the philosophy). They are still living in their Clueless Era, which future enlightened being (enlightened by the philosophy) will preserve in museums (in their Human Clueless Era wings) so as not to forget or repeat their clueless (and absolutely deplorable) past (which current humans are still creating - congratulations) (sarcasm intended).  As for 'component parts', that too is but one perspective, and a limiting one if that is your only perspective. For example, looking for physical component parts will blind you to different levels, especially of function and processes. If you want to roll 'levels' and 'functions' and 'processes' into the phrase 'component parts', then you are into communication confusion, using one word for too many individually identifiable things.  The same holds true on taking perspectives on chaos. There are many, and which one you use (as a mental tool) will depend on the application at hand.

A few months ago, sharp-eyed commenter Z.S nicely caught our Incredibly Learned Professor’s fuzzy naming of Spain as “Alhambra” (the red one), the name of a superlative palace-fortress in the city and province of Granada, instead of Al-Andalus (Land of the vandals), effectively Spain. Its effective administrative center was Cordoba, and not Toledo, which is further north. The Wikipedia article on Al-Andalus (Muslim Spain), and some of its sources, note that each major Muslim city, including Toledo, had its share of libraries, mostly privately owned by the rich aristocrats, with a few public libraries. But the largest book collections (mostly private) and public library were in Cordoba, not Toledo. However Toledo had built a reputation as the major center of intellectual activity in Al-Andalus., mostly for writers, research, translation (a huge business, then, involving Greek, Muslim and Jewish texts rendered into Castilian and Latin.), publishing, and marketing the new books. The buyers of those books remained the richest collectors, the owners of the largest private libraries, in Cordoba and elsewhere. The conquest of Toledo by Alfonso VI of Castile in 1085 marked the first time a major city in Al-Andalus was captured by Christian forces. The reputation of Toledo as a scholarly and publishing center continued unabated.

I thought at first not to comment on this, since I'm no expert on chaos theory.  Nor am I an expert on mathematics, but I do have a degree in physics with a minor in mathematics.  In an open system, this presumption of chaos in the systems we observe in human and biological studies would be correct.  However, in a closed system, it cannot be, and a repetitive condition must occur. In the case of mathematics, this is an open system because it's very theoretical, and for the most part, poorly describes our universe, has many contradictions, and seems to lack some fundamental property that we're all missing, primarily because it's built upon whole integers (and the stuff in-between them) and the base-10 decimal system. An example of having a poor number system was the Roman numeral.  Early Europeans were still using Roman numerals until Fibonacci brought the Arabic numeral system other European mathematicians, but because it was "Arabic", it didn't make widespread use until the 15th century.  If you don't think that the Arabic numeral system is handy, try calculating interest with Roman numerals.  Or try doing geometry, sines and cosines. Could there be a better system of mathematics that we don't know about? At any rate, the next big question is whether or not the universe is an open or closed system.  Notwithstanding the infinite complexities of our current mathematical systems and it's long list of unsolvable problems and anomalies, almost all of these chaotic systems exist only in computers and mathematics.  These instances have little to do with the real world, except that such seemingly simple systems appear to have properties associated with chaotic systems, and may even have formulas to describe them.  The number Pi, for instance.  And the arrangement and order of petals on some flowers as well. If the universe is an open system, then certainly we can ascribe the instances, and indeed, perhaps all things in the universe to having a chaotic nature. If the universe is a closed system, then it depends on whether the universe's exists in an infinite time frame, or the frame is finite. On a finite time frame then, such chaotic systems can exist. On an infinite time frame, all probabilities must exist, including the repetition of any event, and in fact, all events. The problem is that we don't know the answers to any of these questions. I'll borrow this quote to end my thoughts, here, "According to Feynman: I received a telephone call one day at the graduate college at Princeton from Professor Wheeler, in which he said, "Feynman, I know why all electrons have the same charge and the same mass" "Why?" "Because, they are all the same electron!"" I'm certain that this opened a can of worms somewhere in the philosophical community.  However, if it's true, then we're one step closer to a closed universe that ends in a cycle.  That is, infinite, but finitely closed.  And therefore repetitive.

Most audiences of our Incredibly Learned Professor are bewitched by his style of lecturing  — his habit of avoiding too much precision about terribly complex systems, relegating marginal facts to rapid asides, or burdening his public with puzzling nomenclature, in order to focus his energy on his main idea. It may be part of the entertaining hippie image he likes to project, or a genuine personal disinclination (most likely both). For, at heart our Incredibly Learned Professor is a bit of a comedian, a performer, delighting in his Hippie looks and showmanship, his sweeping hand gestures, his amusing mimicry,  the artful modulation of his bass voice, coupled with a sharp, insightful mind. And so, when it comes to the subject itself, he never shies away from navigating the enormous complexity and scope with his customary ease, following the landmarks of his notes spread on the desk in front of him.  More, he delights in his acting ability, carried away by his unstoppable torrent  of loquacity, sometimes amusingly losing the arc of his main idea when tempted by a tangential development, but quickly correcting himself and rejecting the digression. No doubt, his cortex is loaded with intricate networks of fractal bifurcations that he needs to control by following the overall rule highlighted by Lewis Carroll (in his famous poem "Phantasmagoria") to combat the ever-present risk of losing one's way in complex arguments:  "But, keeping still the end in view      To which I hoped to come I strove to prove the matter true By putting everything I knew         Into an axiom."   This highly flexible cortex navigation is the basis of our Incredibly Learned Professor's impressive mental skills. All the synapses in his brain are working extremely well and he usually manages, avoiding the enticing traps of branching out sideways, to resolutely keep his ship  towards its main goal.

Excellent lecture, but I have my criticism of the initial historical note. Professor Sapolsky seems to fall prey of two common issues when discussing historical events, which are temporal compression and overgeneralization. Aside from the dates and places being incorrect, neither the Roman times were as enlightened as we like to imagine nor were Medieval times as dark and ignorant as we often picture them. The Eastern Roman empire kept going for another 1000 years after the fall of Rome, and trading routes in the Mediterranean between Islamic territories, the Byzantine empire and the feudal territories and kingdoms was alive and well throughout the Middle Ages. Moreover, plenty of medieval scholars in Europe were fluent in multiple tongues, including Greek, Latin and Arabic, preserving and translating texts between them.

Medieval Europe had several renaissances, the first one in the 7th century. The knowledge was not lost. The word audit is from centuries later. Don’t worry about higher education. I have two degrees and an advanced diploma in psycholinguistics and all those years of education are a wheat grain compared to what I have learned *because I’m truly interested in it*. I then learned ten or twenty times as much  knowledge by just reading books that sounded interesting or taking free courses online from MIT and Stanford etc. by learning about things I was passionate about in some way I learned so much more.  Also, working on the street helping the homeless and addicted taught me more psychology than my sacred honours degree in cognitive sciences did. Getting a crappy piano caused the creation of more sonatas, concertos and string quartets than a music degree did.  When I got my music degree I ALREADY KNEW EVERYTHING THEY WERE TEACHING! The professors even said after my first year I didn’t need to continue in the music composition degree unless I wanted to be a teacher because I knew everything they were going to teach me! How? Because I was passionate about music. As a teen before university I would hear a beautiful song and get the sheet music and analyze it for days, weeks. I learned counterpoint and harmony from scratch by getting Bach quartet sheet music and thinking “how the hell does he make it sound so good???” I would read the sheet music and make notes on it. First one I figured out was that every note on the beat was part of a chord but the notes not on the beat would be in between the first chord and the next chord. And similar figuring out on and on and on. To the point I knew a degrees worth when I entered the music degree! Also I was a concert pianist during university- I never took a class or practiced in my life. I took one class and he said I was already past what he could teach me. I didn’t practice scales over and over or arpeggios or chords or do etudes or even play other peoples piano music. I literally sat down in front of the piano and saw white keys and black keys and it was low to the left and high to the right, I would push the keys down and yuck, try again yuck again again again and bit by bit I learned piano to master class level. I can play anything. However, as a result of being absolutely self taught, my music is incredibly hard for people taught the normal way to play. Because I didn’t have some person or book droning on about you have to do it like this or that blah blah blah. So my piano music for instance most music uses sets of four note. Do do do do - do do do do - dooooooo. I have 4 fingers and a thumb so instead I would use quintuplets as my basic form. And because I have an amazingly wide finger reach I wrote huge 6 note chords for one hand. It was new, it was different, I wasn’t just following along. In music school I was allowed to skip most classes except the tests and performances. People called me Mozart in a jealous sarcasm, I was the star of the school. I composed on music paper but in an original way, as fractals, a fellow student bought one of my pieces for $300 and framed it because it looked like art visually so different. Point isn’t I’m awesome. Point is *everyone is awesome but life and schooling beats us down and tells us we are less than we are*. I am so happy you’ve found something in this and if you ever want help learning any subject you can message me and I’ll make you a set of videos or a book list so you can learn the subject as deep as you want to! (I’ve also been an autism therapist which includes tutoring them in their schoolwork and finding ways to teach people who learn in different ways) Keep on learning! Follow your interests!

@drew6524  it sounds like you went through a lot of formal education for someone who didn't need it!  I can't think of any concert pianist who doesn't need to practise.  It's one thing to be able to sight read, but to play a great concerto or sonata at a standard that people would want to pay for in a concert hall or in a recording requires talent plus skill that only comes through practice and introspection.  An aptitude for climbing may get you to the top of the mountain more quickly, but it still has to be climbed, and developing the requisite skills is much more easily done within a community of other climbers, whose accumulated experience is available to learn from, rather than having to rely on trial and error, which is draining and time-consuming.  Even genius has to be nurtured.  Did European humans suddenly become more innately intelligent after the discovery of the library in Toledo mentioned by Dr. Sapolsky?  No, they did not.  People were able to acquire knowledge from previous generations that had been lost during the dark ages, and they also came together in pursuit of that knowledge.  Learning is a social experience underaken in a community where learning is valued and recognised, and struggle and failure is recognised as part of the process.

Perhaps my perspective on this is an outlier, but your comment about deeply regretting not going to college and the glamorization of education comes off as repulsive to me.   I have several years of college experience and while I have learned a lot I definitely don't believe it is for everyone nor that it has some great intrinsic value.  Bear in mind I am an autistic genius by nature and have done extraordinarily well in college in terms of academic performance. Even so, I have been increasingly disillusioned from the fantasy of knowledge and education being the holy grail. There is way more to life than learning through formal education or even personal studying. There are way too many things in life that could be learned for a single person to actually learn them. Arbitrary learning is a practice in futility. Although there are many valuable things you could learn they pretty much all fall under the umbrella of applicable skills. It really only makes sense to focus heavily on them if you are likely to apply them in some beneficial way.  I think it would do our societies a lot of good if less people would waste their time learning arbitrary things pursuing a fool's errand of endless knowledge. We need people to focus on useful information that they are likely to apply in the real world.  That said, if you are 75 the most important things in your life have hopefully been accomplished and wishing you had more education seems like a pretty pessimistic way to view the life you have lived. Think of all the other things you got a chance to experience. Maybe you had a husband. Maybe you had kids. Maybe you had grandkids. Maybe your life was better because you had more time for those things.  Let's be honest, education in its most useful application is pretty much a way to achieve wealth and prestige. Neither of those things should matter much at your age.  You bet I'm obsessed with learning and pursuing education and all of that. I have been all of my life. You know why? Because I'm the autistic genius type which exists predominately to serve the purpose of finding new discoveries and sharing them with the rest of the species (for kin/group selection we can presume). Furthermore, as a young adult I'm pursuing wealth and prestige. You bet I am. I have a responsibility to use my unique abilities as a "gift" because otherwise it could be a curse. Being an autistic genius isn't fantastic but when you get lemons make lemonade. I want to use my natural abilities as a power to take care of my family and contribute to the world. That said, if I didn't believe in these significant purposes for my knowledge I certainly wouldn't waste my time pursuing endless arbitrary information.

https://youtu.be/_njf8jwEGRo?t=4043  In complex systems the solutions are imaginary. Yeah, imaginary numbers are part of the solution. That doesn't mean they are a myth, that means you need to use systems of differential equations to solve them. The diagram on the right that you drew has a strong resemblance to the location of an electron in a pi orbital of a diatomic molecule. Its position can be solved probabilistically with the Schrodinger equation. The system remains without predetermination, but with a limited set of possible outcomes and a predictable probability distribution through out its possible states. The complexity phenomenon you are referring to about the breaking point in the number of states of a system is analogous to the ionization energy of an electron as well. It is a physical repercussion of having a system with quantized states that follows Pauli's exclusion principle. I bet you could model that breaking point with something equivalent to Fermi energy, in which a halfway point could be determined in the probabilistic distribution which would represent a point at with the system becomes more likely to tend towards chaos with increasing quantized states or towards a central point with decreasing states.

@AlexBobowski  Triangles exist.... Take two points in space, those two points A and B will ALWAYS make a line, hence the definition of a line (AB) is the distance between two points. These three points with lines AB, BC and AC form a plane with three differing cross sections of lines AB |- BC, AC |- BC, AB |- AC, with each cross section forming an angle that aligns two adjacent lines.
